reviews.review_text: I've been shaking off the urge to write a review for the F2P MMORPG, Rift, for about a week now, purely because I wanted to write one that did it justice. I'm a little under 200 hours into this game at the time of this review, but despite that, I've barely scatched the surface.   I'll start negative. Rift isn't original, I mean sure, the Rift aspect is, but other than that it's pretty much filled with the same content you'd expect from an MMO. Quests that are uncreative, grinding to level and lots of walking, for the most part. So at this point you might be asking yourself why would you play Rift?  Well, in short, Rift does what other MMOs do, but better. The only exception to this, in my view is the spell effects in game are lacking, they feel a little washed out, but everything else, from killing monsters to presentation is absolutely crisp, responsive and highly polished. The scenery is gorgeous, you'll often find yourself stopping to take screenshots and admire the landscape, and even the monsters. Every area has a totally unique atmosphere and feel to it, each crawling with unique monsters waiting to rip your face off. This brings me to difficulty. Rift isn't easy, at least not compared to other MMOs. The monsters and combat are a lot less forgiving, death comes with a penalty and continous deaths with permantly penalize your stats until you visit a healer. This is a good point though, it makes the grinding aspect of the game more enjoyable, because your attention is focused solely on the game in nail biting moments. Look away for even a few seconds and you could come back to find your body laying on the floor surrounded by dragons.   Rift features a huge amount of content. The map is huge, there are several islands to travel, hundreds and hundreds of quests and a huge range of monsters to be killed by. Raids, Chronicles, Rifts, Hunt Rifts, Bounty Hunting, Warfronts, Instant Adventures, Dungeons and so on. To give a perspect on the amount of content, I list eight game types, in just one, for example Dungeons, there is about 40 dungeons in Rift ranging across across levels from 1 - 60. Once you hit 60, it isn't over. You can prestiege and the game introduces a second XP bar for planer attunement, which unlocks new abilities and skills.   I was lucky enough to be invited to a guild on my first day of playing Rift, and I've stuck with it ever since. Joining a guild, working together to do guild quests and form raids/events is where I have the best fun, as I think a lot of people do also. You're able to completely customize your guild to represent and battle others, all the while earning points that contribute to the leveling tree in the guild. This too unlocks perks such as bonus xp, better loot drops, faster health regeneration, teleporting to guild members and so on.   For those of you who may be collectors, don't worry, Rift has a HUGE amount of collectibles in-game, named 'artifacts'. Artifacts are found around the map, either by exploring or by looting monsters and/or chests. Rift encourages exploration, if you can see it, chances are you can go there. You'll be searching for these hidden artifacts for hours and hours, and when you finally do get the complete set for a particular catagory, you get rewards. Rift always rewards you for your work, and it rewards well.   Professions in Rift are quite in-depth, there's enough to keep you digging away for hours, looking for the materials and crafting the items you need to level. The leveling doesn't take too long, there is 375 levels per skill, currently I've managed to achieve this in Fishing, which took about 30 hours or so, just to give a perspective. There is two types of professions; gathering and crafting, both of which tie into one another. You'll be given useful hints and tips as you progress, suggesting which receipes do craft and for what reasons. There is currently about ten professions, give or take, which include: Minning, Butchering, Fishing, Survival, Outfitting, Foraging, Armoursmithing, Weaponsmiths and so on. All the reciepes and materials you craft can either be used, traded or sold either to NPCs are stores or on the player economy driven Auction House.  This game is ENTIRELY free to play, from level 1 to collecting every item, every piece of armour and maxing every skill. There is no restrictions and no cut out content. There is a store, you're able to purchase some items through real money. This is more of a boost, the items can be obtained in-game and no real world purchases are neccesary or required in any way. Spending credits earns loyalty points, which the more you spend, the more you earn. These unlocks are only available via the loyalty system, but can still be obtained absolutely free. There is an in-game item called 'Rex', which you can purchase with game currency, then exchange it for both credits to spend in the store, as well as loyalty points to earn items. This means you can obtain everything in Rift, absolutely free.   As far as MMOs go, this one is one of the best. It's free, it's filled with content and it's crisp in every aspect. I highly recommend you give this a go, it's a little slow to start off, but you'll find yourself hooked and playing daily, enjoying every second of it.   9.5/10 - A fantastic MMO that achieves everything it sets out to do in a high quality fashion.  -0.5 for the lacking spell visuals, it's minor, but noticable.
Edit: My views haven't changed, but I've rewritten the second half to give some clarity to some common complaints I've heard about this review.   How about some balance?

If you are new I wouldn't play this game. There are way to many microtransactions. If you are worried about the grind, don't worry. The game literally doesn't start until you are lvl 65. Everything before that is pretty much a tutorial.  Is the game Pay2Win? Yes. 2 Earring slots have to be paid for with real life money to be unlocked. It used to cost voidstone (One of the myriad of in game currencies) they took that away so they could take cash from their dwindling player base.  Other features. They sell tier 2 gear on the market. People argue that this isn't p2w since T3 has to be earned. The time it takes to earn T2 is a tedious task. As I mentioned there are numerous currencies and notoriety you have to earn with also a bunch of different factions to even buy or use items. The grind for that is tedious, time consuming.   Now that isn't bad, grinding and earning gear. That's what mmo's are about right? Except you spend weeks grinding out currencies because there are caps to upgrade ONE piece of gear. Here is a feel for how many pieces of gear that you can all separately upgrade. Helmet, cape, shoulder, chest, glove, legs, boots, 2 earrings, Neck, Trinket, 2 rings, Synergy Crystal, Seal, Planar Focus and 6 planar essences, two one handed/1 two handed and 1 offhand weapon. All of these require multiple upgrades, cost a VAST amount of in game currencies that is almost impossible to earn unless you have a credit card readily available. And the ongoing insult if cannot perform is “You’re a casual”. Which in itself is dumb. I understand mmo’s require time to get ahead. Yet in this game playing 20 hours a week isn’t enough. You will be left behind in the dust. 40 hours, you better be grinding the whole time. But I suppose non-casuals have played since launch, have been around long enough they already have all the p2w features that Trion has now implemented in their need for greed. So they don’t get the short hand of the stick. PVP … that sums it up honestly. Skill? Non-existent. The maps are neat, the queue times are fast and the idea sounds awesome. Pre-65 pvp doesn’t happen unless you like waiting around for hours for one to pop. The game is heavily, and I mean heavily gear dependent. Forget going into pvp thinking you have a chance. You will just be called a casual because you didn’t swipe your credit card before entering. Since pvp gear caps at about T2 you can buy T2 gear meaning you are good to go for pvp. A fully geared player vs some fresh 65’s could 1 v 5 and not drop below 90% That players skill could be average while the other 5 could be the best players on rift but now are in noob gear. Gear literally makes or breaks everything. Conquest. Don’t bother max gear people just get in premades and walk all over pugs who attempt it. Open world pvp turns into a one sided match. Credit card vs non-credit card. Other factors are people who spent a lot of money on game get awesome boosts like fast mount time, faster mount speed through patron which plays into pvp when someone can cc you and run away and you will never catch up to them. (Very annoying and boring when you actually are winning a fight against team credit card).  So if I had to list pro’s and cons. Pros:  - Pve is fun, boss fights are fun. - Wardrobe is really sweet. All armor collected becomes unlocked as skins for free. - Traveling around isn’t very expensive using the teleporters. - Teaming as you level up isn’t bad. Can queue instant adventures, dungeons, and just join adventures who make their party public to share quest mobs. Cons: - Pay2Win: Buying Earrings. - Gear grind defines your skill.  - Pvp is not fun unless you have gear. Give a toddler a remote detonator for a 50 megaton nuke, and an Adult who is in the Navy Seals a hammer and a one mile gap between that toddler. That defines pvp. The most skilled can get stomped on by those with better gear. Hammer vs Nuke. Who wins? *sigh* - Hard to earn currencies, high currency requirements for upgrades, and weekly caps keep you from doing upgrades for weeks on end for one of your 25-26 pieces of gear.  - Cash Grabs, Cash shops. Taking away from players each update to create a paywall that forces you to buy patron.  - Getting a piece of gear and realizing you need Planewalker: Water. Apparently this zone was free which you can go there for free but you can’t even equip half the gear. It also drops in pvp and in dungeons and usually has nice stats for fresh 65’s.  - Game gets buggy, really laggy as well. I had some weird glyphdebugger come up that forced me to reinstall. I have had a few other friends and family also run into this where they couldn’t even play the game for the entire day. Sucks when you actually pay for patron and can’t even use it. Miss out on daily log in rewards and minion quests that you are trying to collect.  Indifferent: - I don’t mind that there is a cash shop. Selling new souls. (Another powerset tree for your class) That’s fine. They worked hard to create that, it’s an addition to the classes and as long as they aren’t some god mode autowin tree I am fine with it. Charging for some school girl outfit, or a katana is also fine. That is cosmetic. A mount, who cares? Other various features like that, that do not make one stronger or better is fine with me. In the end. I don’t mind a company trying to make money. That’s what businesses are designed to do, if it works, sell it. Yet a business is also supposed to try to support its customers, and Trion doesn’t do that. They seem to want to walk all over their player base and then milk them for more money while making them grind for months on end for gear. So if you want to quit your job, stop going to school, leave your kids at the orphanage and become a recluse then this game is for you. Or you can use your credit card daily if you don’t have the time. Either way it’s a cash sink or a time grab. Game is fun, but with all of this…it isn’t.

One of the best MMORPGs hands-down. I've mainly played this outside of Steam (hence the low playtime), but the depth and level of customization that RIFT gives you for your class is incredible, and blows WoW out of the water. Sure, other things (like the dungeon experience imo) are better in WoW, but RIFT compensates with lots of really cool smaller features that add up quickly. For example, if you outlevel a dungeon/zone, but want to go back and grab the quests, you can set your 'mentored level' down, which essentially allows you to temporarily lower your character's level at will. Player housing is also present, and you can view other player's intricate designs on persistent leaderboards based on user votes. Combat is similar to other ability based RPGs, such as WoW, with the exception on the level of freedom that you get to design your own class. You can manually choose all your abilities from a set of about 10 talent trees (called 'souls') for each class, of which you can have 3 active at once. This means that almost every class can fill almost every role (DPS, tank, support, healer), and you can save your ability sets to allow you to change between roles on the fly (eg DPS → healer), giving each character a lot of versatility. Note that as this game is now free-to-play, some souls are locked behind a paywall, although at £15 if you shop around, it isn't too bad. Moving onto the game's implementation of free-to-play, you can easily complete the game (and the expansions – which are free to access) without paying anything, with all the in-game shop stuff being optional. If you do subscribe (£8.99/month last time I looked), you get the usual XP boosts etc that you would expect from a sub to a free MMO. A nice change however is the fact that the game was originally designed to b pay-to-play, so all the quests and story etc is scaled to those at 100% XP rate – subscribing just allows you to skip out parts as you see fit (and the XP boost can be toggled off). This is a nice change from other games like SWTOR, which feels like it's the subscribers that are getting the 100%, with the free players left at about 75%. Overall, it's a solid offering from Trion, which I feel is equal to, and better than is some cases, WoW.

Having logged 700+ hours on my old account, I installed it on this one simply to write this review. And I can safely say this is the best F2P MMORPG you will ever play. Pros: 1) Even though the combat is tab target, it manages to retain aq dynamic feel. All your skills work together in some way so finding the perfect rotation is always interesting. Combat is also incredibly smooth and is really quite enjoyable. 2) The Soul Tree system is perfect and will find a way to fit your play style effortlessly. You can even have custom classes unheard of in most any other game. A mage that doubles as a tank? If you want. A warrior with group healing? Go for it. A cleric with insane DpS? Hell yeah! 3) PvP is AMAZING. I really can't expand on this any more. Try it for yourself. There is very rarely two players using the same build as there are so many possibilities. Endless fun :D 4) The game has a solid storyline that really engages the players. You feel compelled to continue with the main quest line, although that shouldn't deter you from doing as many side quests as you wish. Quests have decent rewards, such as new equipment and a massive pile of cash.  5) Leveling up isn't a huge grind. Granted, there is some grinding to get new equipment or to get PvP gear. But unlike most, it isn't the same quest in the same area over and over again. The quests can be in different areas, and different objectives.  Cons: 1) Dungeons and monsters can get fairly tricky unless you keep on top of your equipment or have some fairly powerful friends. Join a guild for a group of regular party members. 2) You need a hell of a computer to run this game on anything over medium graphics. I currently have an Intel i5, 8 GB of RAM and a Nvidia 640 GT and I can only run it on high at 50-60 FPS. For max you will really need good components.  3) If you don't pay for subscription, it doesn't affect anything a huge amount but you have a few restrictions that are kinda irritating. i) You can't buy or sell at the auction house.  ii) Pretty small bag space. Probably most annoying. iii) It will take a LOT of grinding, however, to get a mount.  Overall, a very fun, addictive, and engaging game. Definitly one you should get. It's polished and feels like a paid game. The highest praise a free game could have.

Rift carries a D&D style with not so nicely aesthetic characters, tending to more realistic and practical designs, also bringing a few of the usual races of the popular TTRPG system with your classic 'lots of races that are pretty much human' like elves, dwarves, humans and similar variations. Even though that's not it's best point (if you don't like it that is), the game truly shines on what really matters for a MMORPG: Gameplay, Customization and Lore.  Gameplay-wise Rift doesn't rise above most of the titles of the genre, having at least a proper responsive point-and-click combat that feels just right. It is in Customization that this game sells it's name, mostly in Class customization, since it allows your character to freely choose 3 from 8 or 9 (maybe more) talent trees that will both decide skills and passive abilities of your character. Reseting such skills is free of real money charge, so switching builds freely will be pretty much your joy in this game, and something you will wish to have in any title you come across after playing Rift. Character-looks-customization-wise, the game simply offers an equipment look tab that allows you to equip anything you have on it, disabling the equipment stats but prioritizing its looks over the equipment in the normal tab. Simple, practical, effective: Awesome. Lore-wise this game shines probably just like WoW or D&D, it's deep with all kinds of stories in loading screens, NPCs, quests, books to read through the game that can be collected, collectables with stories that become prizes and other things, the game is huge and clearly RP friendly.  If I recommend this game? This is a seriously well built MMORPG, for both a game and for a MMORPG. Edit: I'm not quite sure who the target market for this game is. MOBAs in general have much more lively and balanced pvp matches. And they are f2p as well. Raiding in general is a laggy low-fps jerkfest. My hardware isn't the top of the line, but it handled GTA5 at a decent detail level and framerate. Maybe people who like terrain puzzles and hunting artifacts? Maybe that's the real target market of this game still? Maybe the 5mans? Except that you'll be waiting for a 5man queue to pop maybe once an hour? The scintillating general chat?  Edit: The other thing that annoys me is how the expac souls are engineered to be so much better than the vanilla souls, so that you'll be forced to buy and play the new soul packs. So, if you are say, a mage, you will be forced to play harbinger, whether you want to or not, just because it does the required amount of dps needed to pass the content. Just one example of how f2p ruins a game over time. Another gripe would be how pvp rarely ever feels balanced, where almost every match feels like you're stomping the other team or you're getting stomped on. It's rare you see comebacks or even close scores at the end. It wouldn't matter except that they merged pvp and pve gear together, so that any change in pvp now affects pve, and if there's one thing pvp is always lobbying for, it's change, change, change.  Edit: The thing that really annoys me about this game is the lag. I'm sure that other MMOs do trickery to mask the underlying network latency, and perhaps Trion should look into that. That and the annoying little bugs related to the UI and display that have been in the game since launch. Their QA isn't nearly up to the level that Blizzard's is. And instead of fixing the bugs, Trion seems more interested in rolling out game after game after game. With probably the same sort of bugs in them too.  Edit: Not really pay to win, unless you're willing to shell out $100s. I'm guessing like all freemium models, they're relying on a few big whales to fund the playtime for everyone else. The current level cap 5man experts are decently hard. I can see where they tried to require teamwork, but all it has really done is make the tank shoulder an unequal burden in a PUG. Hence, players willing to tank are rather rare and you will be sitting in an expert queue for quite a while. The entry level raids are also decently hard too and do require even more teamwork to pull off. All in all, if you refrain from being a whale, it's a decent amount of content for not much money. PvP is rather laggy, if you ask me. I asked other people whether this sort of lag was normal and they said yes. So if you like crisp clear PvP, be prepared to be a little bit disappointed.   I played this game when it first came out. At the time, it was quite challenging, the 5man experts required quite a bit of teamwork to pull off properly. I left it when it was still hard, and still a subscription game, mainly because the internet I had sucked at the time. Can't really heal when you're lagging 5000ms. Not really fun either.  I decided to revisit it again, seeing as it's now f2p and subscriptionless, just to see what it's like these days. Everything is now easy mode, you're only in danger of dying if you get out of range of the healer. Otherwise the mobs just die in front of you and give you that sweet XP. The world is also ridiculously easy too, they've set the aggro radius on most mobs to be quite small, it's fairly easy to saunter in somewhere, hit a quest and then saunter back out.  I'm disturbed by the fact that you can now buy purple gear at the level cap. It may be a tier behind and the current tier you may have to play for, but it looks a lot like pay to win. I've no objection to paying for things, and in some ways, f2p makes for a nicer experience. Because nobody's on the clock (either you or the game designers) you don't feel that urgent need to zip through the levels to get to the cap, so you can get on with raiding. And the game designers (who you're really playing against) don't feel that need to slow you down, so they can get more money out of you. Time is money. You want to move fast, they want you to move slow.  But paying to win goes a bit too far. I haven't reached 65 yet (only 55 now), so we'll see.  Everybody (if you're willing to pay for it) can now do every role. Mages, can literally tank. Yes literally. The mage tank is no longer a joke. Warriors, can heal. No, not with bandages. They really can heal.  But if you just want something to kill time with, and all you care about is questing and 5mans, there's a lot of free content they're just giving away. Even if all you do is just dps with one of the original soul combos, it'll probably take you at least a month to get to 65. And then you can just move on to something else :P

I've played many, many MMOs over the years, and this happens to be one out of the five that I keep coming back to. If you are like many people that I have met and have wanted to bring your friends into a game but find that backtracking or making another character is just sooo boring, or sooo painful to do, this is your game. This is the game that ends that. You wanna know how? Simple.  You can delevel yourself without it being permanent, so playing with new player friends, guildies, strangers, or experiencing old content you liked is no longer an issue. Pretty damn sick, right? I've only known Guild Wars 2 to do this, and I really didn't like how it was...forced. But that's because I'm one of those pain-in-the-asses that doesn't like the content to pummel the crap out of me just because I wanted to go and help my buddy on his quest to kill an elite monster.  I'm also a sucker for dungeons and PVE content, and they seem to always be improving. Solo content is also pretty rewarding, but please remember this is an MMO, so you're going to have a ton of those 'kill some rats and I'll give you some silver, pretty boy' quests. Not sure why people complain about that when they know what kind of game this is in the first place.  Do you like roleplaying? If so, they have a dedicated roleplaying server. This is definitely worth looking into seeing as the community isn't all that horrible to each other LIKE SOME GAMES WE KNOW OF. *Cough cough*  I also believe the most hardcore selling point of this entire thing is the customization of your class. You get to mix and match three 'souls' to change up your abilities and buffs. Purchasing more than one specialization to have more combinations of these specs is done with the in game currency rather than the cash, and few of the other souls are locked by the cash as well. Spending money also is very, very worth it, and this is coming from someone that is very stingy if it's a free to play game. I don't believe in throwing my paycheck at something unless it's a damn good deal, and these guys know how to build their microtransaction shop. Plus, the option of a subscription is even better. Nice buffs to your experience gain and gold gain that you can switch off at any time.  If there's anything to hate, it's probably the weird sci-fi fantasy mix of a story they made. I've seen far better. But I'm picky.

Wish I had saved my old review, which was way more thorough than this will be. Not sure why it disappeared. I have another 1500 hours outside of steam (because Glyph client just won't run while steam is active some days; it used to take astrology to figure out the days it would work), across 3 characters + a handful of alts.  Quick summary of the good: + F2P forever, you can earn or find almost all non-vanity items you want without spending a dime + Special class system allows for interesting, non-cookie cutter builds + Good graphics and great atmosphere in most zones + Interesting, engaging questlines with NPCs you will become fond of + Lots and lots and LOTS of content in the vanilla zones + Can shard-hop (server-hop) on the fly while in-game to play with friends in your region + Special world-wide events every few weeks, plus holiday events + One of the servers is named Deepwood, which always makes me chuckle  Bad stuff: - RIFT runs on a heavily modified version of the Gamebryo engine. Your CPU needs to be very good to keep a high fps outside of dungeons and wide open areas. Cities/raids/pvp will crush you otherwise. FPS drops will be less cpu-crushing in the first few zones, but expansion zones have much more clutter in them and will cause lower framerates. - Trion has consistently poor, slow customer service on non-payment matters (quick response/resolution if you have money issues though) - Bugs remain in the game for years before being fixed (or if you're a druid you have 2 abilities that will probably do nothing forever) ; more rehashed content is priority over bugfixing - Unique class system allows many builds but causes big divisions between 'interesting builds' and 'builds which perform well enough to even attempt end-game content' - Not all of the servers have names like Deepwood  Conclusion:  Very enjoyable MMO, great to play with friends or solo, easy to lose yourself in and spend hours and hours playing it. It's free. Try it out! But don't spend money on it, and don't play the end-game unless you get into a good raiding guild before then.  2016 EDIT: Wrote this review in 2014 initially, Rift now has true multicore support and no longer will you get 5 fps in Tempest Bay or Draumheim with a GTX 970. You can easily expect 10 or even 12 fps in crowded city hubs!  AGAIN: don't give Trion your money. Play the 1-60 content because it's honestly fun and you can have a great time with it, but only do the 60-65 content if you have plans to raid and have a guild ready for you. It's a pure grind with bland quests. All of the quality Trion could put into this game at this point has gone towards the raids (they're not terrible, but... not great either).  Starfall Prophecy edit: You thought Storm Legion was a grind? You thought Nightmare Tide was worse? You don't want to know what Starfall is like. Just play from 1-60 and don't even bother with the Plane of Water.

RIFT has some very useful features that makes your game experience a bit more relaxed and enjoyable than the usual MMORPG.  Even if at first it might seem... confusing. Or maybe it's just me getting old and needing some time to adapt to things, in the end you have a product where you are actually incredibly DRAMA FREE.   You can customize your interface, you can decide what do you want to be and create different builds you can easily swap between the same class, so you can actually be A LOT of things in just one character. You won't need to start over 34939 times then regret your first configuration. Everything is adjustable as you play.   There is the very useful NEED/GREED roll dice method, and a public group system that lets you join whatever group of people you encounter in your travels without too much drama and with a very large limit of partecipants.  This makes doing quest that generally require some companions a lot less annoying. Guilds are generally very large and not demanding towards players, due to the fact you actually DON'T really need a guild in this game.   Another peculiar and very wise feature is the fact you actually gain a portion of experience for everything you touch, in the same exact moment you touched it.  Say goodbye to the good old moments where actually farming away something some other player was fighting against was rude and would have made him mad and without exp or without his quest advancements. You can help whoever you want, even if they don't know you, freely.   Also, there are two factions for a good PVP, like in many other games. The same old two factions omg what a surprise, there are the GUARDIANS and the DEFIANTS. But, in PVE servers, you can actually help the other faction's members and freely roam in their territory unless you actually attack them. The only things that would take it bad would be guard NPCs.  But I'm PEACEFUL!!! - Who cares, stay out of the city. - Fine...  I can't say how are things in PVP servers tho, I don't have the mindset for these places.  If following the story and a simple, linear quest line is too BORING for you and you want some senseless, mindless and neverending fight, you will also be able to join some adventures and be added to a huge swarm of people with some common goals to achieve, in a random location, washing away whatever you see.   Being too many levels ahead of your companions will be no longer a problem for none of you two. In RIFT, you can actually decide to lower your lever to whatever level you need. You'll have the same skills and same equipment, but you'll be way less powerful, matching a well equiped character of the level you chose. You will also gain experience according to your actual level, and you will no longer disturb your companion with your skill gaps. This game... I started playing it when my buddy started WoW, I chose this one instead because it was F2P. I almost immediately began spending money on it. Level 60 boost was awesome, patron bonuses are handy, and if you're planning on raiding most classes will eventually need both soul packs (mage being the exception, they only need one of them)  That said, every single one of those things can be purchased through in-game currency, oftentimes at a very reasonable price and especially so if you have nice guildmates. Once you hit the level cap you should be able to farm enough plat by doing your dailies, chronicles, and soloing the old 10 and 20 man raids that you won't know what to do with it, and some of the most expensive essence drops in the game are worth twice as much platinum as both soul packs, an instant 60, and 30 days of patron combined. Having a fat wallet or a gift card will certainly be a boon, but it is not necessary at all, and there is plenty of other content to be had here.  The most important thing I want to stress is about the soul system and how incredibly versatile it is. You can choose to be a Warrior, Rogue, Cleric, or Mage, and each of these callings has 9 unique souls. You pick three of those souls to build a Role, which is like your current class. You can have up to 20 Role slots, and they can be swapped on the fly anytime you're not in combat. This means that, in practice, one character has to be able to fulfill the duties of any member of a raid. In WoW, you might roll a DPS character, and all you do is DPS, but in this game literally anyone can DPS, Heal, Tank, OR Support and each different spec of each different calling has its own situational uses. As a mage, the raid requirements of my guild mean you have to be able to play the following specs:  Stormcaller/Necromancer hybrid - DPS Chloromancer - Heals Stormcaller/Archon - Ranged Turret Support/DPS Harbringer/Archon - Melee movement-friendly Support/DPS Stormcaller - AoE DPS  Each one of these has its own priority list, its own nuances, and its own applications. Not to mention that there are two variants on harbringer/archon depending on if you need to purge, and if you need to burn an add down or simply DPS the boss. There is also Stormcaller/Harbringer, which is arguably the fastest and most difficult spec in the game and yet yields incredible numbers. Not to mention Pyromancer if you need good target-swap burst DPS. And you'll notice, I've only mentioned 6 of the souls, and a handful of the ways they can be combined. As continual adjustments and tweaks to gear and abilities are made, new souls and hybrids will become viable, and others obsolete.  This game is very competitive, and if you enjoy learning in-depth skill trees and experimenting with cutting-edge hybrids to min-max your DPS in any situation, you will find all you could ever hope for and more. On the other hand, if you are very casual, there are always guides out there a few weeks after the top guilds discover a new build or when a soul recieves a large buff. Not only that, but you will never be restricted by your choice of character (ugh, im so sick of healing, i guess i better roll a dps toon and start over from level one.... hah!) and you will never have difficulties finding dungeon groups when any mass of five people can fulfill all 4 roles (tank, dps, heal, support) and have one extra dps.  Bottom line is that this game is extremely deep and rewarding at the end game, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an MMO to occupy their time.

Great MMO if you're looking for something a little different from the usual rhetoric out there.  Positives:  Customisation of classes - With four overarching class types to choose from, each class has several sub-domains that a player can choose, either utilising premade setups, or by creating their own out of three.  Customisation of roles - Tank, Damage, Healer and Support roles are all available to any of the four main classes, depending on the arrangement of subdomains, providing more creativity and player customisation to individual play styles.  World Events - They're per zone, daily and fun. They can also be challenging and often attract up to 25+ players into one area. Additionally, public grouping is an available (and useful) option.  It's isn't pay to win! Yaaay! - Additionally, mounts and pets are lootable, events offer limited items and hard work will pay off if you're looking to purchase real currency items, given the game's tradeable REX.  And there's more, but I don't really have time to get more detailed right now.  Negatives:  I would love to see more players and more development. Other than that, none really come to mind as of yet.  Overall, I definitely recommend this game. I'm an old WoW/EQ player and have had plenty of experience with other MMOs offered, both F2P and P2P.
